Spinach

RECIPE
********
12-15 mushrooms (as big as possible for easy of stuffing)
1 cup onion , chopped
2 pods garlic, minced
1 tbsp Parmesan cheese or nutritional yeast
2 tbsp bread crumbs
2 tbsp baby spinach, chopped 
Salt and pepper
Oil
3-4 tbsp mozzarella cheese
Spring onion or basil leaves for garnish

- Preheat oven to 410 F
- Wash the mushrooms well and remove the stem from cap. Chop the stem and set it aside.
- In a pan, add 1/2 tbsp oil and add onions, garlic and chopped mushrooms. Saut√© till onions are caramelized.
- Add spinach, bread crumbs and Parmesan cheese and cook for 2-3 mins. Add salt and pepper to taste and set it aside to cool down.
- Spray the mushrooms caps with oil and start stuffing the mixture. 
-Top with mozzarella cheese and bake for 15 mins at 410F or till cheese browns up 
- Set on serving dish and top it off with herbs and serve! Enjoy!

Wishing everyone a Happy Varalakshmi vratham üå∫

This is a Hindu festival celebrated on Second Friday of Sravana MƒÅsam, where married women worship Goddess VARALAKSHMI DEVI(Goddess who grants boons), and observe fast and pray for the well being of their husband, kids, and family. As I learnt from my nanamma(grandma), amma that worshipping VARALAKSHMI DEVI on this day is equivalent to worshiping of ASHTALAKSHMI- the eight forms of goddesses of Wealth, courage, prosperity, wisdom, nourishment, victory, progeny and the protector.

The day starts with cleaning the house, taking bath and performing pooja of all deities at home and then the VARALAKSHMI DEVI idol or photo is placed and pooja is performed. Telangana, or as we say BANGARU TELANGANA meaning golden Telangana. A state with home to age-old traditions and is known for its rich history, diverse cultural heritage, and architectural grandeur. Now coming to the Telangana cuisine, it is a gastronomic delight in its beautiful rustic way of cooking. The region‚Äôs hot climate, cultural heritage, and a bit of an influence of neighbor state cuisines, made it a rich cuisine which has been unnoticed from many decades. The state capital has its own charm, culture and cuisine completely different from the countryside. Our Curries have quite bold flavors like spicy, sour, nutty. And we love spicy sour food, most of our dishes curry/stew/chutneys include tamarind. Hefty use of garlic is what makes it unique and stand out. And it‚Äôs pretty shocking to believe that only 1.2% of Telangana are pure vegetarians and the rest have Meat cuisine as the mainstay. PƒÄPADƒÄLU, PƒÄPADLU
A quintessential Indian summer ritual!! 

Making papads is an absolute must in many Indian traditional households. For generations, families engaged in this exercise and followed age-old recipes some of which treasured family secrets. Papads take several people back to their childhood homes ‚Äî joint families and huge terraces. 

Making papads makes me nostalgic and takes me right back to my childhood. I remember how right after my exams during the summer vacations, my mother and grandmother would plan ahead on how to execute the papad making process. It was my duty to check on papads and flip them in between. And the best part of this exercise was eating the raw papad while the elders were looking away.

Amma used to make atleast dozen varieties of papads and fryums. The sheer variety of flavors and techniques she makes is what I like most. Kandhadalu is my absolute favorite, we make these with poha, puffed rice or a mix both with various flavors like raw mango, cilantro, tomato and lemon cucumber. And another childhood favorite of mine is koradalu, fryum which got its name because it looks like a whipping rope. Among all these varieties one thing that remains constant is the generous usage of sesame seeds, in every single papads we make you would see sesame seeds in it, that‚Äôs what makes it our signature style Telangana regional papads. In Hindu traditional weddings in Telangana, we have a ritual of making papadalu kandhadalu, made of urad dal flour and hefty amount of sesame seeds that are some shaped like cutlet and some rolled as papads, this is later fried and served to the bride and groom on the 16th day wedding festivities. A tradition that is still followed religiously in many homes.

Tindora and Moringa  leaf Chutney 

Ingredients 
Tindora 100 gm roughly chopped 
Moringa leaves, stalks removed 1 handful
Green chilli 5-6
Tamarind small gooseberry size
Coriander seeds 1 tbsp
Cumin seeds 1/2 tbsp
Fenugreek seeds 1/4 tsp
Sesame seeds 1.5 tbsp
Mustard seeds 1 tsp
Dry whole red chilli 2
Curry leaves a few 
Oil for sauteing and tempering 

Method 
Heat oil in a pan . Add the coriander seeds, cumin seeds, Fenugreek and fry. Once they start turning brown add the green chillies and tamarind, and  continue to fry. When the chillies start changing color add the sesame seeds and roast again. Once the sesame seeds start to splutter, transfer to a blender jar.
Pour some more oil into the pan and saute the tindora for 3-4 mins. Now add the Moringa leaves and saute for a minute. Add salt at this stage , turn off the flame and allow to cool completely.
Now grind the roasted ingredients in the blender. Add the sauteed Tindora and Moringa leaves and blend everything together to a smooth paste.
Transfer to a bowl. Take oil for tempering in a pan. Add mustard seeds, , whole red chilli, asafoetida and curry leaves. Once the mustard seeds splutter, add this tempering to the prepared chutney. 
Enjoy with hot rice and ghee or as a side for Chapatis.

Small serve cheesecake ingredients 

For the glaze/ sauce 

150 GM fresh strawberries hulled and chopped
Sugar 1/4 cup
Lemon juice optional- I didn't use it as the strawberries were a little tart
Corn flour 1/2 tbsp, make a slurry with 3 tbsp water

Method for sauce
Add the Strawberries and the sugar to a pan and turn on the flame. Cook on low flame until the strawberries turn tender. Keep washing with a ladle now and then. If using lemon juice, add now. When the sauce starts bubbling and spluttering, add the cornflour slurry, stir until the sauce thickness, and turn off the flame. Cool completely. Store it in the fridge until required.

Ingredients for Cheesecake 

Cream cheese 1/2 cup
Condensed milk 1/4 cup
Corn flour 1 tbsp
Prepared strawberry sauce 1/4 cup ( optional)

Ingredients for base

6-8 biscuits, use any. I used Mom's Magic butter biscuits 
Butter 2 tbsp

Method - line a tart pan or spring foam pan with butter paper. Crush/ pulse the biscuits , add melted butter, and mix well. Transfer this into the prepared Tart pan and press firmly to distribute it well to the edges.
Now blitz the ingredients given under cheesecake ingredients in a blender and pour it over the biscuit base. 
Now take a bigger oven proof vessel ( into which the tart pan will fit) pour a little water, and place the Tart pan into it. Preheat the oven at 160 for 10 mins. Bake at 160 degrees for 35-40 mins, or until a fork inserted comes out clean. Allow to cool completely before demolding. Top it with Strawberry sauce or any seasonal fruit sauce and dig in.

JARDALOO SALLI MARGHI ~ Parsi chicken curry is a beloved dish that beautifully represents the unique culinary heritage of the Parsi community in India. 

Jardaloo‚Äù means apricot in Gujarati, ‚ÄúSalli‚Äù refers to potato sticks or matchstick potatoes and ‚ÄúMarghi‚Äù or ‚ÄúMurghi‚Äù means chicken.
 
Very few spices are used in this dish and the main heroes are apricots and potato sticks. The combination of apricots and vinegar and sugar give a lovely sweet and sour flavour that is highly prized and characteristics of the Parsi cuisine. In the traditional version of this recipe, potatoes are cut into thin sticks and deep fried.

Finding raw and sour mangoes in some parts of USA is still rare. When such rare occasions present themselves, I like to celebrate by making this favorite pachadi (chutney) - Mamidikaya Badhallu or Menthi mukallu.

Recipe:

ü•≠Menthi Badhalluü•≠

Raw mangoes - 2 (wash, wipe dry and remove inside pit. Cut into small pieces with the skin)
Fenugreek seeds - 1TBSP
Mustard seeds - 1 TSP
Asafoetida - 1/2 TSP
Dry red chilies - according to your taste 
Salt - as needed 
Sugar - a pinch 
Turmeric powder - 1/4 TSP
Sesame oil - 1/4th cup

Method:

In a pan heat oil for tempering, add fenugreek seeds, mustard, red chilies and asafoetida. Fry until the mustard seeds crackle.
Once this mixture is cool to touch, filter out the oil. Transfer the ingredients into a blender and grind to a fine powder. 
In a large bowl mix the chopped mangoes with salt, sugar, turmeric powder and the ground masala. Blend in the filtered out oil. Let this mixture sit for an hour in the bowl. Stir well, check for salt and spice. Add chili powder if you prefer spicier. Enjoy!

Oil

Dry red chili - as needed

First grind the dry masala ingredients to a fine powder and then add the veggies, grind everything together to a coarse paste. Mix in the mashed tomatoes. Stir well. 
Roast the tempering ingredients and add on top of the chutney just before serving. Enjoy!
